item.title: Lecture 3 - Data wrangling, munging and creating tidy datasets
item.description: Today’s Agenda Review data importing, cleaning and munging data Creating tidy datasets Using the tidyverse In-class tidy’ing Data wrangling Data wrangling or munging is the process of going from raw to useful data. This can be 60-80% of the time spent on a project. Data Wrangling Cheatsheet Steps may include any or all of the following: Step Examples Import read.

item.title: Lecture 2 - Data structures, Reproducible Research, loading, cleaning and munging data in R
item.description: Today’s Agenda Review the concepts of Reproducible Research Review Git Importing, cleaning and munging data Summarizing and exploring data Vectors, matrices, and data frames Reproducible Research | Review This was the scenario: You had worked 6 months to analyze a data set. Someone else analyzes the data and comes to different conclusions. How good are your notes??? Answer: Awesome, because you annotated your code with text to create a RR compendium

item.title: About
item.description: This class is STAT 5014. It is a 1 credit P/F class designed to get students up to speed with R and at least aware of other languages. At 1 credit, we do not have time to cover many advanced topics. I will introduce topics and I will provide lots of reading material for those interested in learning more. Course material Generally, there will be 3 parts: Lecture slides – html style markdown Example code – html style markdown Homework – knitted pdf and the corresponding Rmd I am including both pdf and html markdown to provide examples for those that are interested.

item.title: Configuring Docker -- Work in progress!!
item.description: Nothing to do here!! This is really a work in progress for me. OK, decided to ditch the local config. In spite of the fact that Docker is supposed to be platform agnostic, it needs some sort of virtualization layer, so some versions of Windows are a no-go, eg Windows Home Ed. We will use Docker in Docker and use Singularity to launch it. Let’s talk a little about Docker.

item.title: Git Conf
item.description: Note, this is a working document describing how we will use git in this class. Every students local computing platform is different and we will see exceptions. Please do this early and let me know if you have issues and see deviations that should go on this writeup. Basically, we need to have:

item.title: Lecture 1 - Introductions, Reproducible Research, (a little) R, and (a little) Git
item.description: Today’s Agenda Introduce the course Introduce the concepts of Reproducible Research Introduce Git Introduce R as the (main) platform for the course Homework 1 Course Learning Objectives R programming Reproducible research concepts Good programming practices Data cleaning and munging Git fundamentals Markdown Python basics SAS basics Tentative Course Lecture Schedule Due dates are solid, however, feel free to race ahead. https://rsettlage.github.io/STAT_5014_Fall_2020/schedule/

item.title: Submitting homework
item.description: Homework submissions will be accomplished through GitHub. At this point, I am assuming you have worked through the Git Configuration document and successfully added the README file via the command line.
